Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 01:40PM chinablue wrote: I am struggling with the same issue.  I have no family history of bc, but here I am at age 47 with stage III. Should I get tested?  Would I want my daughters tested?   Wouldn't it place such a huge burden on them.  I have read about women that have prophylactic mx and hysterectomies at young ages.  Geez, I don't want that for my daughters.
Posts.Title: To Test or Not To Test.... squidgee mawhinney

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 07:17PM - edited Feb 10, 2010 07:18PM by chinablue My onc suggested that I get tested.  It would be covered by my insurance.  It is my understanding of genes that someone can be a carrier and not necessarily present with bc.  Also, genes are funny. I might have inherited a gene from a great Aunt i never knew.  Still, I don't know if I want to do the test.  My sister in law, a very highly regarded doctor, thought it would be a good idea to get tested so that I might easily qualify for any upcoming PARP clinical trials.   Heavy sigh.
Posts.Title: To Test or Not To Test.... squidgee mawhinney

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2010 02:26PM chinablue wrote: Jayne I finished chemo 5 weeks ago.  I have no hair yet, just white fuzz on my head.  The numbness/tingling has improved on my fingers, but remains on my feet and toes (ug).  I am thinking better though and have more energy.  Rads are going well (10 down) and I have no real se's.    The snow is melting here in NY and the air is starting to feel like Spring.  With Spring, I feel like it will be a fresh start with great hope.  Ironically, I will end rads on Good Friday.  I think Easter will bring new life.   I wish everyone well.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2011 01:28PM chinablue wrote: I had the exact symptoms.  My fingers did get better about 6 months after taxol.  My feet got marginally better and I can exercise and walk fine now (18 mos out).  I just try to ignore the tingling (as if my feet are asleep).  It is better if I keep my feet warm.  Ug boots are the best.   I also had oozing black finger nails....ahh memories.   It got so that buttoning my blouse was difficult, but my onc said it was better than cancer, so I muscled on.  He offered to put me on Cymbalta, because he said it would make me feel better. Its an anti-depressant with a side effect that helps neuropathy.  I just did not want to go down that route.  I was so afraid of cancer that I muscled through all 12 taxol treatments. That is just my story.  I wish you the very best.

Posts.Title: Weschester and Rockland Ladies crusader1 Jisman

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2009 11:06AM chinablue wrote: My breast surgeon said the complete report would take at least 10 days post op.  This is a Sloan Kettering NYC so nothing had to be "sent out" of the hospital itself.  Originally, I put a great deal of weight onto the path report.  I do to a much lesser extent now because I feel my doctors and I did everything we could for the moment.  In my mind, the path report will determine the type of "cocktail" the oncologist will put together for chemo.  Of course, I am curious.  Chemo will start in September so I am asking myself to relax in calm before the next storm.  Right now, I am celebrating the fact that I took a shower by myself (10 days post op unilateral mast/diep reconstruction).  I am able to walk around my block and I am going to church today.  It is one day at a time for me.   Ask yourself will it really change anything to wait a day?  It might for you.  Maybe the report will help your state of mind.  In which case, push for it!  Why not the report is yours?   On the other hand, if I looked at my path report without an expert to decipher it I would probably feel more unsettled.    Good Good Luck
Posts.Title: Anybody get their path results BEFORE follow-up with surgeon? tovahsmom dee1961
